page.title: 14The Harringworth Viaduct 2
page.content:
This Viaduct, completed in 1878, spans the Welland from Seaton to Harringworth. 2,500 men helped to build it, and they were paid between Â£1 and Â£3 per week, according to their skills. Huts were erected to house these workers, and the Railway Mission came to try to convert them. They were said to be a 'rough and ready lot' by the local residents, and were often caught drunk or poaching.
Many of these immigrant labourers, or 'navvies' would have moved on once this branch of the Midland Railway was built, but some settled. Certainly, the lurcher dogs they liked to keep are still found in the area.
The land belonged to Colonel Tryon, great-grandfayher of the present landowner, Mr G.T.G.Conant.
